Award.AwardTitle: Direct Modeling of Star Clusters in Galaxy Formation Simulations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The scientists will numerically simulate the origin of star populations in our Galaxy. The study will include a novel approach to modeling star clusters directly in galaxy formation simulations. They seek to unravel several unsolved puzzles in our understanding of Galactic formation and evolution: (i) What caused multiple generations of stars within massive globular clusters? (ii) What is the fraction of halo stars stripped off globular clusters? (iii) Was the bulge assembled by early mergers or by gradual transformation of the Galactic disk?

They will implement the cluster formation and evolution model in the cosmological adaptive-mesh-refinement code (called ART) and run several realizations of Milky Way-sized galaxies with different environment and merger history. ART is a powerful galaxy formation code and already includes non-equilibrium cooling and heating of cosmic gas, non-equilibrium formation and dissociation of molecular hydrogen, thermal, kinetic, and radiative feedback of young stars, transport of ionizing radiation, and other important processes. Inclusion of clustered star formation will add a realistic description of stellar populations, with a well-defined stellar initial mass function and more concentrated feedback on the interstellar medium (ISM). The simulations will produce a rich data model, and will be used to interpret various observations of Galactic clusters and dwarf satellites.

They will integrate the simulations into a program of state-of-the-art scientific visualizations of galaxy formation over cosmic time. The visualizations will be designed for display at the University of Michigan Planetarium, and will be viewed by thousands of elementary, middle and high school students in the Detroit metropolitan area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the course of this project PI Oleg Gnedin and graduate student Hui Li have developed a novel algorithm for modeling star formation in cosmological galaxy formation simulations. It simultaneously follows the formation of new star clusters and their feedback on the parent molecular cloud, similar to how observational astronomers see it. We created a suite of simulations of galaxies like the Milky Way and investigated the evolution of their star clusters. The analysis of these simulations constituted the core of Li's PhD thesis. After graduation he moved on to a postdoctoral position at MIT, to work on ultrahigh-resolution simulations of molecular clouds. In 2019, Hui was awarded a prestigious Hubble Fellowship to combine the modeling of cluster formation with large-scale galaxy formation.

PI Gnedin continued analysis of this simulation suite with two current graduate students, Gillen Brown and Xi Meng. Brown and Gnedin investigated the chemical evolution of simulated galaxies and the origin of anomalous abundances of heavy elements in massive globular clusters. Xi and Gnedin investigated the predicted structure of high-redshift galaxies and the properties of their stellar populations.

In parallel, PI Gnedin and undergraduate student Nick Choksi developed an analytical model for star cluster formation and evolution that complements the simulations - it uses the formation rate derived from the simulations as input but allows a much faster computation for multiple globular cluster systems. We used this analytical model to investigate the age and metallicity distributions of observable globular clusters at the present time, the origin of the mass-metallicity relation of massive metal-poor clusters, and the build-up of the globular cluster-halo mass relation. The model has also been extended to study the formation and merger rate of stellar-mass black hole binaries in clusters (potential sources for detection by LIGO), and the formation of millisecond pulsars (potential explanation for the diffuse gamma-ray emission detected by Fermi Space Telescope around the center of our Galaxy and the Andromeda galaxy).

This project leaves a lasting impact on the field. The analysis of our simulation suite provides the most detailed and realistic prediction of the formation and evolution of massive clusters throughout cosmic time. In addition, our analytical model provides a convenient and accurate framework for quantifying any phenomena occuring in massive star clusters: compact objects, tight binaries, sources of X-ray and gamma-ray emission, and gravity waves.
